Award.AwardTitle: Cost/Value Allocations in Supply Chain Operations

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cooperation among manufacturers has the potential to create a robust network of financially successful manufacturing firms that is essential for the resurgence of manufacturing in the US. These firms stay nimble by maintaining independent ownerships and keeping their sizes small. But they can also benefit from economy of scale enjoyed by large enterprises by joining forces with other members of their supply chain. Quantity discount in procurement, risk pooling in inventory control, and cost efficiency in environment regulation compliance are just a few examples of advantages that can be achieved by cooperation. Because firms are motivated to pursue their own interests, value sharing and/or cost allocation schemes are of vital importance for the formation of stable cooperative relationships. Cooperative game theory lays out a general framework for identifying and analyzing these schemes. Nevertheless, combining the general theory with supply chain specifics to develop implementable solutions and algorithms is a major challenge, which will be tackled in this project. This research will provide analytical tools to determine whether a mutually profitable cooperation is possible for a given set of manufacturers, and if so, identify allocation schemes to sustain the relationship.

This research will analyze cooperative games in supply chain systems, such as the Newsvendor model and the Economic Lot Sizing model. The analysis will be also extended to more general versions of these systems that feature multi-period decision-making, price-demand relationships, concave inventory costs, and finite demand windows. The aim is to develop general conditions under which non-empty cores exist and identifying possible monotone allocation schemes. The underlying optimization problems that characterize individual participants' behavior and determine the outcome of the games, are difficult and will be addressed by new optimization techniques developed during this research. Moreover, the project will consider not only the effect of allocation schemes on incentive to cooperate, which is a verifiable action, but also participants' effort levels, which are not directly observable. Therefore, in addition to willingness to participate, the design of the value sharing/cost allocation scheme also needs to take into account incentive to contribute, and the development of such schemes in this project will add a new dimension to the existing models in the supply chain literature.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Forming a robust cooperative network can help many small businesses to be competitive and financially successful, which is essential to maintain a vibrant US manufacturing sector.  Cooperation allows firms to be nimble by staying small and retaining individual ownership, while also able to join forces to derive the same advantage from economy scale enjoyed by giant enterprises with large supply chains.  Quantity discount in procurement, risk pooling in inventory control, and cost efficiency in complying with environment regulations are just a few examples of these benefits.  To keep the cooperation stable for firms that are motivated to pursue their own self-interests, it is important to develop sustainable mechanisms for sharing values and dividing costs. Game theory, which study cooperative and non-cooperative games, and combined forms of both, lay out a basic framework for designing and analyzing these mechanisms. In this project, we bridge the gap between the general theory and supply chain management by developing analytical tools to determine the existence of mutually profitable cooperation, and if it does, design value/cost allocation schemes to sustain the relationship.

 

We have analyzed several supply chain systems, including the classical Newsvendor model and the Economic Lot Sizing model. We have also generalized our study for advanced forms of these systems, by incorporating features like dynamic control over multiple periods, price-demand relationship, and resource-constrained decision-making. We have developed general conditions and allocation mechanisms to provide incentives for firms to cooperate and share their risk/cost. We have created analytical tools for these new business models and developed novel optimization techniques to address technical challenges involved. Our new models and techniques make significant contributions to the literature of supply chain management and provide frameworks, tools and insights to understand and facilitate various forms of cooperation in practice.   Our research have produced several major publications in top-tier academic journals, and provided graduate students with rigorous training in quantitative methods and prepared them for careers that require cutting-edge analytical skills.
